column1: Fort Walton Beach is a city in southern Okaloosa County
column2: Florida
column3: United States. As of 2010
column4: the population estimate for Fort Walton Beach was 19
column5: 507 recorded by the U.S. Census Bureau. It is the principal city of the Fort Walton Beach−Crestview−Destin Metropolitan Statistical Area.

column1: Fort Walton Beach is a year-round fishing and beach resort community. Its busiest time of the year is the summer
column2: causing a boost to the local economy because of seasonal human migration.

column1: == History ==

Prehistoric settlement of Fort Walton Beach is attributed to the mound building "Fort Walton Culture" that flourished from approximately 1100~1550 AD. It is believed that this culture evolved out of the Weeden Island culture. Fort Walton also appeared to come about due to contact with the major Mississippian centers to the north and west. It was the most complex in the north-west Florida region. The Fort Walton peoples put into practice mound building and intensive agriculture
column2: made pottery in a variety of vessel shapes
column3: and had hierarchical settlement patterns that reflected other Mississippian societies.

column1: The first Europeans to set foot in what is now Okaloosa County and the Fort Walton Beach area were members of Álvar Núñez Cabeza de Vaca's party
column2: who traveled by boat from what is now Panama City Beach
column3: Florida in 1528 to Texas
column4: "Then we set out to sea again
column5: coasting towards the River of Palms. Every day our thirst and hunger increased because our supplies were giving out
column6: as well as the water supply
column7: for the pouches we had made from the legs of our horses soon became rotten and useless. From time to time we would enter some inlet or cove that reached very far inland
column8: but we found them all shallow and dangerous
column9: and so we navigated through them for thirty days
column10: meeting sometimes Indians who fished and were poor and wretched people".

column1: The area is described at "40 deaths a day" in a Spanish map dated 1566. In later English and French maps the area of was noted as "Baya Santa Rosa" or "Bay St. Rose". A number of Spanish artifacts
column2: including a portion of brigantine leather armor
column3: are housed in the Indian Temple Mound Museum.

column1: Contrary to popular belief
column2: there is no documentary evidence of pirates using the area as a base of operations. Piracy was rampant in the Gulf of Mexico from pirates working out of Hispaniola
column3: the Caribbean
column4: and the Florida Keys. Notable raids occurred in 1683 and 1687 against the Spanish fort at San Marcos de Apalachee (by French and English buccaneers)
column5: a 1712 raid against Port Dauphin (now Alabama) by English pirates from Martinique
column6: and the actions of the late 18th-century adventurer William Augustus Bowles
column7: who was based in Apalachicola. Bowles was never referred to as "Billy Bowlegs" in period documentation; his Creek name was "Eastajoca".

column1: During the era of Spanish and English colonization
column2: the area of what was to become Fort Walton Beach was noted in several journals but no worthwhile presence was established.

column1: Early settlers of Walton County
column2: Florida were the first to establish permanent settlements in what is now Fort Walton Beach (the area was originally named "Anderson"). One of the first settlers was John Anderson
column3: who received land plots in 1838. The name "Anderson" is noted on maps from 1838 to 1884. It was not until 1911 that the name "Camp Walton" appeared on Florida maps.

column2: Camp Walton was a Confederate Army camp
column3: a fortified post
column5: an independent Company  of Florida Volunteer Infantry from Walton County. At this time
column6: Okaloosa County did not yet exist. Walton County received its name from Col. George Walton
column7: who served as secretary of West Florida during Andrew Jackson's governorship (1821-1822) and whose father
column9: was the 56th signatory of the Declaration of Independence. As a result of Col. Walton's influence in the politics of north-west Florida
column10: his name was honored by establishing Walton County.Camp Walton was located between the Indian Temple Mound
column11: now known as the Heritage Park and Cultural Center
column13: its mission was to protect the "Narrows" from Union ships. Although the "Walton Guards" did not see much action
column14: they did keep busy by digging up prehistoric Indian remains buried in the Indian Temple Mound and displaying them at camp. The post was abandoned in August 1862
column15: and the "Walton Guards" were assigned to reinforce the 1st Florida Infantry Regiment
column16: with duty in the Western Theatre on the Tennessee front.On April 11
column18: John Thomas Brooks purchased at a public auction in Milton
column23: a portion of the property of Henry Penny whose heirs had failed to pay the taxes on the estate. This parcel on the Santa Rosa Sound became what is now downtown Fort Walton Beach.

column1: The United States Post Office changed the official name on their cancellations from Camp Walton to Fort Walton on 1 March 1932.
The 1940 census counted 90 residents in Fort Walton. Fort Walton was incorporated  by a  State Senate bill effective June 16
The community's name was officially changed from Fort Walton to Fort Walton Beach on June 15
column3: by agreement with the state legislature in Tallahassee
column4: and incorporated a portion of Santa Rosa Island formerly known as Tower Beach. Tower Beach
column5: named for a tall observation tower at the site which was later destroyed by a hurricane
column6: had been an amusement area operated from 1928 by the Island Amusement Company by future-Fort Walton Beach mayor Thomas E. Brooks
column12: and concession stands which was largely destroyed by fire on Saturday
column14: 1942. Wartime supply restrictions prevented a reconstruction.  This 875-acre parcel of Santa Rosa Island with three miles of Gulf frontage was conveyed to Okaloosa County on July 8
column15: 1950 in an informal ceremony at the county courthouse in Crestview
column16: Florida. The county paid the federal government $4
column18: the result of the efforts of Congressman Bob Sikes. The portion of Santa Rosa Island transferred is now known as Okaloosa Island. The remaining Tower Beach summer cottages were removed after the 1955 tourist season as the new Okaloosa Island Authority redeveloped the site with a new hotel and casino.   The government was changed to a city manager form.A special census conducted in 1956 listed 9
column21: 249 by 1960.The last of three county-owned buildings on Okaloosa Island was torn down on May 31
column22: 1995. The buildings had originally housed the Okaloosa Island Authority and more recently the Okaloosa County Council on Aging. The 1.3 acre tract on the north side of Santa Rosa Boulevard was sold.

column1: == Geography ==
Fort Walton Beach is located at 30°25′13″N 86°37′00″W (30.420199
column2: −86.616727). According to the United States Census Bureau
column3: the city has a total area of 21.3 km2 (8.2 sq mi)
column4: of which 19.3 km2 (7.5 sq mi) is land and 2 km2 (0.77 sq mi)

column1: === Climate ===
Fort Walton Beach experiences hot and very humid summers
column2: generally from late May to mid-September. Autumns
column3: from mid-September to early December
column4: are generally warm. Winters are very short and mild
column5: from mid-December to late February. Springs are warm
column6: from late February to late May.

column1: Fort Walton Beach
column2: part of the western Choctawhatchee Bay region of which Destin and Niceville are also part
column3: is very wet
column4: averaging 69 inches of rain each year
column5: more than any other city in Florida. The wettest season is summer
column6: and the driest season is autumn
column7: although flood season continues into autumn.

column1: Snow and freezing rain are very rare. Freezing rain occurs about once every 5 to 10 years. Snow occurs about once every 10 to 15 years. The most recent measurable snowfall was on January 31
column3: when about 1 inch (25 mm) fell in Fort Walton Beach
column4: while 3 inches (76 mm) fell on Crestview
column5: about 27 miles (43 km) inland. The most recent report of a trace of snow was on January 28
column6: 2014. The last report of freezing rain was on February 11

column1: The Köppen Climate Classification subtype for this climate is "Cfa" (humid subtropical climate).
== Transportation ==
=== Airports ===
Nearby Destin-Fort Walton Beach Airport (airport code VPS) serves Fort Walton Beach
column2: as well as Valparaiso
column3: Florida. Airlines that currently serve Destin-Fort Walton Beach Airport are Allegiant Airlines
column6: and Delta Connection. They provide non-stop service to Atlanta

column1: No longer Uptown station but at the Elders Center close by.
Okaloosa County Transit  [1]  provides public transportation throughout Fort Walton Beach as well as Okaloosa County. Its main stop and transfer location is Uptown Station located on State Road 85
column2: a little over 1 mile north of US 98.

column1: === Major highways ===
State Road 189 is a north-south highway from State Road 85 to US 98 in downtown Fort Walton Beach. State Road 85 is a north-south highway that leads north 27 mi (43 km) to Crestview
column2: the Okaloosa County seat (also along Interstate 10)
column3: and ends at US 98 in downtown Fort Walton Beach. US 98 is an east-west highway
column4: which runs through downtown Fort Walton Beach. The Brooks Bridge over the Santa Rosa Sound connects downtown Fort Walton Beach with Okaloosa Island
column5: which is along the route of US 98. US 98 leads east 9 mi (14 km) to Destin and west 41 mi (66 km) to Pensacola.

== Economy ==
The economy of Fort Walton Beach is driven by two primary factors: tourism and the military. There are two major Air Force bases which border Fort Walton Beach. Hurlburt Field is home to Headquarters
column2: Air Force Special Operations Command (AFSOC)
column3: the 1st Special Operations Wing
column4: and the Joint Special Operations University.  Eglin AFB is home to the Air Force Materiel Command's Air Armament Center and the 96th Air Base Wing
column6: and Air Combat Command's 33rd Fighter Wing.   Eglin is geographically one of the largest Air Force bases at 724 square miles (1
column8: and thus home to joint exercises
column9: and missile and bomb testing. For example
column10: the 'Massive Ordnance Air Blast' or 'Mother of All Bombs' (MOAB) was first tested at Eglin AFB on March 11

column1: There is support industry in the area that benefits from the presence of the bases
column2: including military contractors and the service industry. Companies based in Fort Walton Beach include Lee's Famous Recipe Chicken and ResortQuest.

column1: The tourism industry is seasonal
column2: with summer being the primary season
column3: and a smaller peak season during spring break.  The area also boasts a large snowbird population
column4: which includes the Fort Walton Beach Snowbird Club.  The Billy Bowlegs Pirate Festival is held annually in June.
